title-group.article-title: Employer-Provided Health Insurance and the Adverse Selection Problem

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Marco A. Castaneda is an assistant professor in the Department of Economics at Tulane University. He received his PhD in economics from Washington University in St. Louis. His research focuses on the economics of organization in the presence of incomplete contracts and asymmetric information, the economics of not-for-profit organizations, and the behavior of the different types of organizations in the hospital industry.

James Marton is an associate professor in the Department of Economics in the Andrew Young School of Policy Studies at Georgia State University. He is also a faculty affiliate of the Georgia Health Policy Center, the Partnership for Urban Health Research, and the W. J. Usery Workplace Research Group. Marton received his PhD in economics from Washington University in St. Louis. His research examines the financing of public and private health insurance programs.

abstract.p: The role of employers in the health insurance market in the United States is substantial, but there is little formal analysis investigating how the introduction of employers affects the structure of equilibrium contracts in the health insurance market. In this article, the authors present and analyze a model of employer-provided health insurance and show that if the labor market is competitive, the equilibrium must be a separating equilibrium, as in the standard model. The key to this result is that insurance companies and employers have similar incentives because health insurance is an important component of total compensation. In addition, the authors show that if workers bargain collectively for employment contracts, the equilibrium can be a separating or a pooling equilibrium, but in any equilibrium, the low risks obtain more insurance than in the standard model and subsidize the insurance premiums of the high risks.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The study of employer-provided health insurance is of considerable importance because of the number of individuals in the United States who obtain their health insurance through their employer, largely due to the tax subsidy associated with employer-provided health insurance premiums. In addition, employer-provided health insurance may serve as a mechanism to pool risk types, which may be socially desirable.
1
However, there is little formal analysis investigating how the existence of employers, as intermediaries between insurance companies and individuals, affects the structure of equilibrium contracts in the market for health insurance. Moreover, a proper understanding of employer-provided health insurance is necessary to better understand how various aspects of the new health care reform (Affordable Care Act of 2010), such as the creation of health insurance exchanges and the excise tax on high-cost employer-provided health insurance plans, would affect the market for health insurance.
2

The primary purpose of this article is to investigate how the introduction of employer-provided health insurance affects the structure of equilibrium contracts in the market for health insurance. In order to analyze this question, we extend the standard model and consider a situation in which individuals obtain their health insurance from their employer, and employers obtain the menu of insurance policies to offer to their employees from the insurance companies. The main results of the article are as follows: if we assume the insurance industry is competitive and maintain the same information structure and equilibrium solution as in the standard model, (1) if the labor market is perfectly competitive, the equilibrium must be a separating equilibrium as in the standard model, but (2) if the labor market is not competitive, and individuals bargain collectively with an employer over employment contracts, in general the equilibrium will exhibit cross subsidization and less-risk segmentation and in some situations will be the pooling equilibrium with full insurance.

For the intuition, consider the break-even pooling policy with full insurance. As is well known, because of the single-crossing property, there exists another policy which would be preferred to the break-even pooling policy only by the low-risk types and which would generate a strictly positive return for an insurance company. Moreover, if an insurance company offers a menu with the deviating policy, an employer would have an incentive to choose such a menu and offer a slightly lower wage, and this offer would be attractive to the low-risk types and would generate a strictly positive payoff for the employer. Therefore, if the labor market is perfectly competitive, the employers and insurance companies will have similar incentives, because health insurance is an important component of the total compensation and expected utility of an individual, which implies the equilibrium must be a separating equilibrium.

Alternatively, if individuals bargain collectively with an employer over employment contracts, and the union representative maximizes the total utility of the individuals, the equilibrium can be a pooling equilibrium, where the individuals purchase the break-even pooling policy with full insurance. In addition, in order to induce full participation and prevent adverse selection, in equilibrium, the employer pays part of the employee’s insurance premiums. The intuition behind this result is that, for a given level of total compensation, the menu of insurance policies does not affect the payoff of the employer. Therefore, the menu which arises in the negotiations must be the menu which maximizes the preferences of the union representative, which in general will exhibit cross subsidization and less-risk segmentation and in some situations will be the break-even pooling policy with full insurance.

The seminal article on the structure of equilibrium contracts in the market for health insurance is Rothschild and Stiglitz (1976) (henceforth, RS). The primary results of the RS model are that (1) a pooling equilibrium, in which every health-type purchases the same policy, does not exist and that (2) a separating equilibrium, in which each health-type purchases a distinct policy, may not exist if the proportion of high-risk consumers in the economy is relatively low. Moreover, if there exists a separating equilibrium, in equilibrium only the high-risk consumers obtain full insurance, which may be suboptimal from a social perspective.

The nonexistence of a pooling equilibrium in the RS model is of particular concern because, as discussed in Crocker and Snow (1985) and Encinosa and Sappington (1997), the break-even pooling policy with full insurance may be considered as the socially preferred policy, in the sense that it maximizes the sum of the individuals utilities or the expected utility of an individual who does not know their type. Therefore, the problem of the nonexistence of a pooling equilibrium, and the possible nonexistence of a separating equilibrium, has motivated a number of other articles which consider variations of the original RS model. For instance, to address the possible nonexitence of an equilibrium, Wilson (1977), Miyazaki (1977), and Spence (1978) altered the equilibrium concept by explicitly considering reactions to new contract offers, and Dasgupta and Maskin (1986a,b) extended the original model by considering mixed strategies. In these situations, an equilibrium always exists.
3

Finally, more closely related to our article is the article by Crocker and Moran (2003) who consider employer-provided health insurance but alter the information structure of the model. In particular, individuals learn their health type ex post and may choose to switch employers, based on the type of insurance contracts offered, but switching employers is costly. In this situation, a pooling equilibrium with full insurance may exist if the switching costs are large enough. In addition, Bhattacharya and Vogt (2006) analyze a similar model and derive similar results. The theoretical models in these articles do not involve asymmetric information and are based primarily on the implications of “job switching” costs, while the model presented here is based primarily on the adverse selection problem and the implications of the ability of workers to bargain collectively over employment contracts.
4

The analysis of our model in which individuals bargain collectively with an employer over employment contracts is motivated by the history of employer-provided health insurance. According to Thomasson (2003a), the market for health insurance in the early 1900s was relatively small because commercial insurance companies lacked the information to accurately calculate risks and premiums and were concerned with the adverse selection problem. However, in the 1930s, the Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans began to take advantage of the fact that adverse selection can be mitigated in the health insurance market by selling insurance to groups of employed workers (Thomasson 2003b). In particular, employed workers are relatively healthy and represent a diverse set of risks because they are not assembled due to their demand for health insurance. Moreover, group sales allow insurance companies to take advantage of economies of scale. The successful strategy of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans was quickly imitated by commercial health insurance companies, who began to move rapidly into the health insurance market.

In addition, several factors contributed to further growth in the health insurance market in the United States in the 1940s and 1950s, including several public policies that encouraged the consumption of employer-provided health insurance. In particular, the 1942 Stabilization Act limited the ability of employers to offer wage increases but allowed employers to offer health insurance plans. According to Scofea (1994), this stimulated the growth of employer-provided health insurance through collective bargaining agreements with labor unions. Moreover, a 1949 ruling by the National Labor Relations Board, which was later upheld by the US Supreme Court, held that, when negotiating for wages, unions are allowed to negotiate for pension and health insurance benefits as well (Thomasson 2003b; Scofea 1994). Finally, the 1954 Internal Revenue Code explicitly stated that employer contributions to employee health insurance plans are exempt from the taxable income of an employee (Thomasson 2003a), which further increased the incentives of unions to negotiate for employer-provided health insurance.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. The Model section presents the basic framework for our analysis of employer-provided health insurance. The Equilibrium with Perfect Competition section presents the equilibrium analysis assuming the labor market is perfectly competitive. The Equilibrium with Bilateral Bargaining section derives the equilibrium assuming the individuals bargain collectively with an employer over employment contracts. The Discussion and Extensions section discusses the main assumptions and possible extensions of the article. Finally, the Conclusion section concludes the article with a discussion of the policy implications.

Technically, this is a game of imperfect information, because the type of an individual is private information, and the appropriate equilibrium concept is that of subgame perfect Bayesian equilibrium. However, because the players with the private information move at the end of the game, the system of beliefs is trivial and the notion of a subgame perfect Bayesian equilibrium reduces to the simpler notion of a subgame perfect equilibrium. Therefore, a combination of strategies for the insurance companies, employers, and individuals is said to be an equilibrium if its a subgame perfect equilibrium of the associated extensive form game. That is, the strategy of each player is a best response to the strategies of the other players in every subgame. An equilibrium is said to be a separating equilibrium if in equilibrium each type purchases a different insurance policy.

An equilibrium is said to be a pooling equilibrium if in equilibrium every type purchases the same insurance policy. We now proceed with the equilibrium analysis.

The main intuition behind this result is that there is a sense in which the employers have the same incentives as the insurance companies. In the standard model, the insurance companies compete directly for the individuals. In the model with employer-provided health insurance, employers compete for the individual but insurance is an important component of the total compensation and expected utility of an individual. Moreover, the competition for workers induces the employers to consider the preferences of the individuals when interacting with the insurance companies, which implies the standard results. To summarize, we have introduced a model of employer-provided health insurance to investigate how the introduction of employers into the standard health insurance model may affect the equilibrium contracts. The analysis was motivated in part by informal claims in the literature suggesting that employer-provided health insurance may generate more pooling in the health insurance market, but our results in this section indicate that the introduction of employers alone may not generate a pooling equilibrium if the labor market is perfectly competitive. Therefore, in the following section, we consider the possibility that the labor market may not be perfectly competitive. In particular, we consider the opposite extreme and investigate the equilibrium of the model with bilateral bargaining.

The material in this section is motivated by the historical conditions when employer-provided health insurance began to emerge, as discussed in the Introduction. In particular, we consider a situation in which there is only one employer and the individuals bargain collectively with the employer over the employment contract, which consists of the wage, the menu of health insurance policies, and the amount of the insurance premiums to be paid by the employer. Moreover, we assume the individuals are organized as a union, for the purpose of collective bargaining, and the objective of the union representative is to maximize the total welfare of its members.

Finally, we maintain the same assumptions about the information structure, the structure of the insurance industry, the production technology of the employer, and the preferences of the individuals.

The results from our model have a number of testable implications and are consistent with existing empirical evidence. For instance, the empirical results in Bhattacharya and Vogt (2006) indicate that individuals with specialized skills specific to the employer are more likely to have employer-provided health insurance. Moreover, they interpret their empirical results as consistent with their hypothesis “that pooling is more likely in industries where the costs of job switching are higher.” In a similar way, the empirical results in Crocker and Moran (2003) indicate that individuals with higher levels of employer-specific human capital have higher levels of coverage. Finally, Buchmueller, Dinardo, and Valletta (2002) summarize and provide new evidence of the effects of collective bargaining on employer-provided health insurance. In particular, individuals covered by collective bargaining are more likely to have employer-provided health insurance, and the employer pays a higher fraction of the health insurance premiums.

The theoretical models in Bhattacharya and Vogt (2006) and Crocker and Moran (2003) are based primarily on the implications of “job switching” costs and are considerably different from the model presented in this article (although job-switching costs can easily be included in our model). In addition, the results from our model provide additional testable implications about the effects of collective bargaining on the structure of employer-provided health insurance contracts. As a summary, our analysis suggests that it is the combination of employer-provided health insurance and collective bargaining by the workers that may result in less-risk segmentation and a pooling equilibrium.

sec.title: Discussion and Extensions
sec.p: In this section, we discuss the main assumptions of the model and how alternative assumptions may affect the previous results.

sec.title: Differences in Productivity
sec.p: There are a number of simplifying assumptions in the model, and the assumption of equal productivity across individuals and types deserves additional discussion. This assumption is made for simplicity, but there are a number of alternative assumptions which could be adopted, in terms of how differences in productivity are correlated with health types and whether differences in productivity are observable.

For instance, consider the model with perfect competition and suppose there are differences in productivity across individuals, possibly correlated with their health type. This may be a reasonable assumption because one can think of a number of reasons why a certain risk type may be more or less productive. Then, if the productivity of an individual is observable and uncorrelated with their type, the main results of the article would continue to hold, but in equilibrium, each individual is paid a wage equal to their marginal productivity. In a similar way, if the productivity of an individual is unobservable and uncorrelated with their health type, we obtain the same results, but in equilibrium, individuals are paid a wage equal to the expected marginal productivity. In conclusion, if there are differences in productivity across individuals, and the productivity of an individual is observable or uncorrelated with their health type, the main results of the model with perfect competition continue to hold.

Therefore, the more interesting situation is one in which there are differences in productivity across individuals and the productivity of an individual is unobservable and correlated with their health type. For instance, suppose productivity and risk type are negatively correlated, which implies the low-risk types are more productive. This may be true because the low-risk types are less likely to become sick and health problems are less likely to interfere with their work. In this situation, the main results of the article continue to hold. In particular, there does not exist a pooling equilibrium because now the employers have a stronger incentive to adopt a deviation from the break-even pooling policy, because such a policy is attractive only to the low-risk types and the low-risk types are more productive.

Alternatively, suppose productivity and risk type are positively correlated, which implies the high-risk types are more productive. For instance, the high-risk types may be more productive because they have more experience. In this situation, the results in the model with perfect competition may not hold. The employers do not have the same incentives as the insurance companies, because a deviation from the break-even pooling policy is attractive only to the low-risk types, which have a lower productivity. Therefore, if an insurance company offers a deviation from the break-even pooling policy, such deviation would not be adopted by any of the employers without a lower-wage offer commesurate with the lower productivity of the low-risk types. Moreover, if such a deviation is adopted by an employer, the employer may not be able to attract any workers because of the lower-wage offer. Therefore, in this situation, a pooling equilibrium may exist. Intuitively, because the low-risk types are less productive, in a pooling equilibrium in which the individuals are paid their expected marginal productivity, the low-risk types subsidize the insurance premiums of the high-risk types and the high-risk types subsidize the wages of the low-risk types.

In the model with bilateral bargaining, differences in productivity across individuals and types does not affect the results. The reason for this is that, for a given level of total compensation, the equilibrium menu of insurance policies maximizes the preferences of the union representative. Therefore, the analysis and the results would be similar, except that the payoff of the employer would be computed as the expected payoff, given the distribution of productivity across individuals and types. However, the pattern of cross subsidization of individuals will be different and will depend on whether productivity is positively or negatively correlated with the health type. In other words, when individuals are equally productive, in equilibrium, the-low risk types subsidize the premiums of the high-risk types. However, if individuals differ in their productivity, there will be an additional subsidy where the high-productivity individuals subsidize the low-productivity individuals. Therefore, depending on whether productivity is positively or negatively correlated with the health type, it will be more or less likely that the equilibrium will be the pooling equilibrium with full insurance, but the results would remain qualitatively the same.

sec.title: Employers Pay Insurance Premiums
sec.p: In the model with perfect competition, we assumed the individuals pay the full premium associated with their health insurance policy. Alternatively, we may consider a situation in which the employers pay the full premiums or a situation in which the employer pays only a fraction of the premiums. In these situations, the main results from our model with perfect competition would continue to hold, but the structure of the equilibrium may depend on the types of offers the employers can make to the individuals.

For instance, suppose an employer must offer the same wage and menu of insurance policies to every individual, but the insurance premiums are fully paid by the employers. In this situation, if an employer offers a menu with multiple insurance policies, every individual will choose the insurance policy with the most coverage, because the premiums are paid by the employer. In other words, there cannot be separation of types within a given employer. However, this does not imply that there exists a pooling equilibrium. In fact, the equilibrium must be a separating equilibrium in which (1) a subset of the employers offers the menu with only the separating policy

sec.title: Information Constraints
sec.p: In the model with perfect competition, we assume the individuals observe the wage and menu of insurance policies offered by every employer. This assumption may not be completely reasonable, as few individuals have complete knowledge of the types of insurance policies offered by a prospective employer. Moreover, an insurance policy can be relatively complex, and the description of a policy may include, in addition to the deductible and coinsurance rate, a description of limitations in the choice of provider and the types of procedures covered. Generally, individuals know the wage offered and whether the employer offers some type of health insurance, but they do not observe the menu of insurance policies offered until they begin working for the employer. This could potentially alter the results of the article.

Intuitively, a pooling equilibrium does not exist because the incentives of the insurance companies and the employers are similar. This is driven by the fact that health insurance is an important component of the total compensation and expected utility of an individual. Therefore, there may exist a pooling equilibrium if employers cannot capture, in the form of lower wages, some of the increased utility from offering a better menu of insurance policies. This situation may arise if individuals cannot observe or it is costly to observe the menu of insurance policies before they choose an employer.

Therefore, suppose individuals do not observe the menu of insurance policies offered by an employer before they choose an employer. As in the previous analysis, we model this situation as an extensive form game of imperfect information where nature makes the initial move and determines the type of each individual, which is private information. Then, (1) the insurance companies simultaneously offer a menu of insurance policies to the employers, (2) the employers observe the offers from the insurance companies and simultaneously choose a wage and a menu from one of the insurance companies, and (3) the individuals observe the wages offered by the employers, but not the menu of insurance policies, and simultaneously choose an employer to work for and subsequently an insurance policy from the menu offered by the selected employer.

Technically, if we assume the individuals do not observe the menu of insurance policies offered by the employers, we must specify what the individuals believe, about the menu of insurance policies offered by the employers, when they select one of the employers. Informally, in a subgame perfect Bayesian equilibrium (1) the strategy of each player must be sequentially optimal given their beliefs and the strategies of the other players and (2) for any information set reached with positive probability, the beliefs must be consistent with the strategies of the players.

The previously described strategies and beliefs are a subgame perfect Bayesian equilibrium. The strategies of the individuals are optimal, given their beliefs. Moreover, the beliefs of the individuals may not be entirely reasonable, but they are correct at information sets actually reached, given the strategies of the other players. In addition, no employer has an incentive to deviate because in order to attract any workers the employer must offer a wage at least equal to the marginal productivity of an individual, which results in a expected payoff of zero. For the same reason, insurance companies have no incentive to deviate. Intuitively, the key to the previous result is the difference in the incentives of the insurance companies and the employers. In particular, because individuals do not observe the menu of insurance policies offered, if other employers offer a wage equal to the marginal productivity of an individual, an employer receives a payoff of zero independently of the menu of insurance policies selected. Therefore, the employers can block any deviations from the insurance companies which would break the pooling equilibrium. A weakness of the previous analysis is that any menu of insurance policies can be implemented as a subgame perfect Bayesian equilibrium. However, not every equilibrium may be reasonable, because most of them are Pareto dominated.

There is a similar but possibly weaker assumption which generates the same results. This would be to assume that individuals have lexicographic preferences with respect to the wage and the menu of insurance policies. Here, individuals choose an employer-based primarily on the wage, and only look at the menu of insurance policies when multiple employers offer the highest wage. This assumption may capture the intuition that in most situations, as long as an employer offers some type of health insurance, the exact menu of insurance policies offered by an employer plays only a minor role in an individual’s decision whether or not to work for that employer. As with the previous assumption, if other employers offer a wage equal to the marginal productivity of an individual, an employer cannot attract any workers with a lower wage, independently of the menu of insurance policies selected. Therefore, the assumption of lexicographic preferences would generate the same results.

Finally, implicit in the structure of the model is the assumption that insurance companies cannot offer monetary incentives to the employers to adopt a particular menu of policies. In particular, there exists a menu of insurance policies which would separate the types and generate a strictly positive payoff for an insurance company.

Therefore, an insurance company would have an incentive to offer such a menu and a small monetary incentive to any employer who adopts the menu offered. In this situation, an employer would have an incentive to adopt such a menu because of the monetary incentive, even if such a menu does not otherwise increase the payoff of the employer. This would break the pooling equilibrium. Therefore, if the insurance companies can offer monetary incentives to the employers, the equilibrium must be a separating equilibrium as in the standard model, even if the individuals have lexicographic preferences or do not observe the menu of insurance policies before choosing an employer.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The primary purpose of this article was to investigate how the introduction of employer-provided health insurance affects the structure of equilibrium contracts in the market for health insurance. The main results of the article indicate that the structure of the labor market has important implications for understanding how the introduction of employers affects the market for health insurance. In particular, if we maintain the same information structure and equilibrium solution as in the standard model and assume the labor market is perfectly competitive, then the equilibrium must be a separating equilibrium as in the standard model. Intuitively, the insurance companies and employers have similar incentives because health insurance is an important component of the total compensation and expected utility of an individual.

Alternatively, if individuals bargain collectively with an employer over employment contracts, there will be less-risk segmentation. In particular, compared to the separating contracts implied by the standard model, in our model, the low risks obtain a higher level of coverage and subsidize the premiums of the high risks. Moreover, if the equilibrium level of total compensation (which depends on the disagreement payoffs, the productivity of the workers, and the relative bargaining power of the employer) exceeds a certaint threshold, the equilibrium is the pooling equilibrium with full insurance. Finally, in order to induce full participation and prevent adverse selection, the amount of the insurance premiums paid by the employer is strictly positive. This may help explain why employers have traditionally paid a relatively large fraction of the premiums associated with the health insurance of their employees. Therefore, our results suggest that it is the combination of employer-provided health insurance and collective bargaining by the workers that may result in a pooling equilibrium.

The recently passed health care reform (Affordable Care Act of 2010) may be more accurately described as health insurance reform legislation rather than health care reform legislation since it primarily focuses on increasing the rates of health insurance coverage. One way in which the increase in health insurance coverage will be paid for is through an excise tax on high-cost employer-provided health insurance plans. In addition, a key component of the new health care law is the creation of health insurance exchanges, where individuals can purchase health insurance at affordable rates, possibly with a government subsidy. Therefore, the health care law could potentially alter the role of employers and the structure of equilibrium contracts in the market for health insurance.

Intuitively, most people obtain their health insurance through their employer due to (1) the tax exclusion on employer-provided health insurance premiums and (2) relatively affordable premiums based on experience rating for this relatively healthy group. Therefore, if the new health care law decreases the tax subsidy associated with employer-provided health insurance and the health insurance exchanges can offer individual health insurance at relatively low rates, it may no longer be optimal for some employers to offer employer-provided health insurance to their employees. Alternatively, some employers may obtain health insurance for their employees through the health insurance exchanges, and this may be particularly true for employers whose experience rating implies relatively high premiums. This implies the health insurance exchanges may experience the adverse selection problem, which is the main reason why many previous exchanges, such as those in Texas, Florida, and California, have not been very successful.

Finally, the results in our article indicate that, if individuals bargain collectively for employment contracts, employer-provided health insurance encourages pooling of risk types and mitigates issues associated with adverse selection. Therefore, any policy changes that decrease the gains from employer-provided health insurance, such as taxing employer-provided health insurance premiums, must be examined carefully. Among other things, the taxing of premiums could lead to more risk segmentation in the market for health insurance, particularly in industries with a strong union presence. As discussed in Feldman and Dowd (2000), risk segmentation results in inefficient limitations on coverage for low-risk individuals. In addition, an increase in risk segmentation can have distributional consequences, as it forces high-risk individuals to pay more for a given level of coverage.

There have been many recent policy proposals involving the reduction or elimination of the tax subsidy for employer-provided health insurance premiums. For instance, President Bush proposed eliminating the current tax subsidy and replacing it with a new standard deduction in the federal income tax for all who obtain a qualifying health insurance policy through their employer or directly from an insurance company.

The standard insurance problem has been analyzed from a number of perspectives due to the institutional structure of the health care system. For instance, Encinosa and Sappington (1997) investigate how the introduction of HMOs, which provide health insurance as well as health care services, affects the structure of equilibrium contracts. They show that, in the presence of market power or economies of scale, a pooling equilibrium may exist in their model.

In the context of employer-provided health insurance, a separating equilibrium can take several forms. For instance, each employer may offer a menu with multiple policies, and each type chooses a different policy. Alternatively, each employer may offer a menu with only one policy, but each type may choose to work for a different employer and purchase a different policy.

This implies the “utilitarian” welfare function (over the welfare of the employees). We believe this is a reasonable assumption, given that the individuals are identical except for their risk type. In addition, this is equivalent to maximizing the ex ante expected utility of an individual (before the individual learns his or her type). Finally, although this assumption is convenient, we cannot think of a more reasonable assumption.

The model with perfect competition does not have any implications for the amount of the premiums paid by the employer. However, as discussed in the next section, the results are consistent with the empirical observation, in the sense that there exist equilibria in which the employers pay part or all of the premiums.
This is the menu that a monopoly insurance company would choose if the individuals obtained their health insurance policy directly from the insurance company.
